response:
Neurophysiology is required to confirm focal peripheral nerve involvement and define axonal versus demyelinating pathology; blood tests and urine studies should search for systemic vasculitis, autoimmune disease, metabolic and infectious causes; imaging and, if needed, nerve biopsy and genetic testing further clarify aetiology and guide immunotherapy.

investigations = ["Nerve conduction studies and electromyography of all four limbs", "Full blood count", "Urea and electrolytes", "Liver function tests", "C-reactive protein", "Erythrocyte sedimentation rate", "Fasting blood glucose", "HbA1c", "Serum vitamin B12", "Serum folate", "Thyroid-stimulating hormone", "Serum protein electrophoresis", "Serum immunofixation for monoclonal protein", "Serum free light chains", "Antinuclear antibody", "Extractable nuclear antigen panel", "Rheumatoid factor", "Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibody", "Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies", "Complement C3 level", "Complement C4 level", "Hepatitis B surface antigen", "Hepatitis C antibody", "HIV antigen/antibody test", "Serum cryoglobulins", "Urinalysis for blood and protein", "Urine protein:creatinine ratio", "Chest X-ray", "Ultrasound of the right ulnar nerve and left common peroneal nerve", "MRI of brachial plexus and lumbosacral plexus with contrast (if neurophysiology suggests proximal lesions)", "Lumbar puncture for cerebrospinal fluid protein and cell count", "Sural nerve or superficial peroneal nerve biopsy", "Genetic testing for PMP22 deletion/duplication"]
